title: Serious sync issues
body:
Version: jq-1.6

These commands:

> echo '{"version": "v1"}' > /tmp/eventsheet.json
> 
> cat /tmp/eventsheet.json | jq --arg next_var "1" '. + {next_var: $next_var}' > /tmp/eventsheet.json2 && mv -f /tmp/eventsheet.json2 /tmp/eventsheet.json
> 
> cat /tmp/eventsheet.json | jq '. + {next_var: 1}' > /tmp/eventsheet.json2 && mv -f /tmp/eventsheet.json2 /tmp/eventsheet.json
> 
> cat /tmp/eventsheet.json | jq --arg vars "[]" '. + {vars: $vars}' > /tmp/eventsheet.json2 && mv -f /tmp/eventsheet.json2 /tmp/eventsheet.json
> 
> cat /tmp/eventsheet.json | jq '. + {vars: []}' > /tmp/eventsheet.json2 && mv -f /tmp/eventsheet.json2 /tmp/eventsheet.json

Have resulted in this:

> {
>   "version": "v1",
>   "next_var": 1,
>   "vars": []
> }
> }

It have one more "}".

The commands are correct, but it seems that jq have sync issues when writing to json files (excellent at reading but not so at writing).

Its an Electron app, but I had similar write sync issues from this bash program: https://github.com/DaniellMesquita/Web3Updater

@stedolan

title: visibility of wiki pages
body:
The visibility of wiki pages to search engines is generally limited; for example, the search result for "jq Cookbook" looks like this:

```
jq Cookbook - GitHub
https://github.com ‚Ä∫ stedolan ‚Ä∫ jq ‚Ä∫ wiki ‚Ä∫ Cookbook
No information is available for this page.
```

Even worse, Google sometimes moves references such as this to somewhere near infinity in the search results.

To help alleviate the near invisibility of the Cookbook and FAQ to people using search engines, it would greatly help if hyperlinks to these pages could be added at the top of https://stedolan.github.io/jq/ and/or the jq Manual.

Thanks.

title: Fix typo
Compile error messages don't provide column only line number
body:
**Describe the bug**
Compile errors in filter expressions don't include the column number where the parser approximately or exactly locates the error. Most filter expressions are one-liners (are multiple lines even supported?), so the information that the error is on line 1 is not helpful.

Example (I'm not seeking support to make the filter work!):

```
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
..nodes[ ?( @id == 1 ) ]
```

**To Reproduce**
Create a query with an erroneus filter expression.

**Expected behavior**
The error output should provide information where the parser approximately or exactly locates the error in the line, e.g.

```
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1, column 12:
..nodes[ ?( @id == 1 ) ]
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS and Version: Ubuntu 21.04
 - jq version: 1.6

**Additional context**
./.

title: Strange behavior on output parsing
body:
**Describe the bug**
jq formatting floating point numbers to Scientific Notation differently for similar output.

**To Reproduce**
curl -s https://api-pub.bitfinex.com/v2/tickers?symbols=fUSD :
[["fUSD",0.00015455068493150685,0.000135,120,16992566.8081159,0.00009212,2,1248170.4817084703,-0.000004,-0.04,0.000096,170277504.11872676,0.000135,1e-8,null,null,353935968.57143486]]

curl -s https://api-pub.bitfinex.com/v2/tickers?symbols=fUSD|jq :
[
  [
    "fUSD",
    0.00015455068493150685,
    0.000135,
    120,
    16992566.8081159,
    9.212e-05,
    2,
    1248170.4817084703,
    -4e-06,
    -0.04,
    9.6e-05,
    170277504.11872676,
    0.000135,
    1e-08,
    null,
    null,
    353935968.57143486
  ]
]

curl -s https://api-pub.bitfinex.com/v2/tickers?symbols=fEUR :
[["fEUR",0.000047246575342465755,0.000075,120,155740.75316847,0.00002111,2,42180130.94364965,-0.00002127,-0.2127,0.00002211,11394595.81270521,0.00004864,0.00000416,null,null,42108608.0037314]]

curl -s 'https://api-pub.bitfinex.com/v2/tickers?symbols=fEUR'|jq :
[
  [
    "fEUR",
    4.7246575342465755e-05,
    7.5e-05,
    120,
    155740.75316847,
    2.111e-05,
    2,
    42180130.94364965,
    -2.127e-05,
    -0.2127,
    2.211e-05,
    11394595.81270521,
    4.864e-05,
    4.16e-06,
    null,
    null,

]

So for fUSD 0.00015455068493150685 is not converted, but for fEUR 0.000047246575342465755 is converted to 4.7246575342465755e-05
For fUSD 0.000135 is not converted, but for fEUR 0.000075 is converted to 7.5e-05

title: Support binary strings, preserve UTF-8 and UTF-16 errors
body:
The internal string representation is changed from UTF-8 with replacement characters to a modified form of "WTF-8" that is able to distinctly encode UTF-8 errors and UTF-16 errors.

This handles UTF-8 errors in raw string inputs and handles UTF-8 and UTF-16 errors in JSON input. UTF-16 errors (using "\uXXXX") and UTF-8 errors (using the original raw bytes) are maintained when emitting JSON. When emitting raw strings, UTF-8 errors are maintained and UTF-16 errors are converted into replacement characters.

As well as being able to be used as a "pretty printer" without risk of corrupting binary data (eg, JSON strings such as "\uDC00\uD800!", or arbitrary bytes in input), it is now possible to pass around arbitrary files either as JSON or raw data (using ill-formed UTF-8):

```
$ sha1sum jq
ff8e6e9fd7d87eb1c9179da546ccbbcd77a40f14  jq
$ ./jq -n '$a' --rawfile a jq | ./jq -j | sha1sum
ff8e6e9fd7d87eb1c9179da546ccbbcd77a40f14  -
$ base64 jq | ./jq -jR '@base64d' | sha1sum
ff8e6e9fd7d87eb1c9179da546ccbbcd77a40f14  -
```

To demonstrate UTF-16 error preservation:

```
$ node -e 'console.log(JSON.stringify("üí©".split("")));'
["\ud83d","\udca9"]
$ node -e 'console.log(JSON.stringify("üí©".split("")));' | ./jq .
[
  "\ud83d",
  "\udca9"
]
```

Fixes at least #1931, #1540, #2259.

title: fromdate yields incorrect result
body:
**Describe the bug**
Tried to parse dates to calculate relative time between an ISO date and "now", got negative results which shouldn't be possible.

**To Reproduce**
```
$ date -ud @$(jq -n '"2021-04-22T15:55:48Z" | fromdate')
Thu 22 Apr 2021 04:55:48 PM UTC
```
As you can see, the parsed date is off by one hour.

**Expected behavior**
I expect the time to match the input.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS and Version: Linux Debian Testing
 - jq version: 1.6

**Additional context**
The problem does not occur on all machines. I suspect it has to do with the configuration of the system's Real Time Clock.
For compatibility with my dual-booted machine's Windows install I have
```
               Local time: Thu 2021-04-22 18:16:12 CEST
           Universal time: Thu 2021-04-22 16:16:12 UTC
                 RTC time: Thu 2021-04-22 17:21:45
                Time zone: Europe/Amsterdam (CEST, +0200)
System clock synchronized: yes
              NTP service: active
          RTC in local TZ: yes
``` 
Most significantly: `RTC in local TZ: yes`. It feels like, `jq` is parsing the date as if it were my local timezone, although that would explain a 2-hour offset, not a 1-hour offset... So maybe there is some compensation in the wrong direction?

title: seg fault when regex split a string with connector punctuation at word boundary (jq 1.6 macOS)
body:
**Describe the bug**
I get segmentation fault trying to split a string containing a Unicode "connector punctuation" character at word boundaries. 
I then tried with a Cyrillic letter (‘î) and got the same result.

**To Reproduce**
`echo '"a bÔπèc d"' | jq 'split("\\b";"")'` ("Segmentation fault: 11" or "jq quit unexpectedly" when calling jq from VSCode)
https://jqplay.org/s/Y1mXHvy9mx ("signal: segmentation fault")

**Expected behavior**
`["a","bÔπèc","d"]` or at least not a segfault.

**Environment**
 - jq 1.6
 - macOS 10.11.6
 - Terminal reports `LC_CTYPE=UTF-8`
 
**Additional context**
Most probably an Oniguruma thing.
- I have read [kkos/oniguruma/blob/master/doc/RE](https://github.com/kkos/oniguruma/blob/master/doc/RE) and there is no Unicode note about `\b`.  
- I noticed `y{?}: Text Segment mode` and tried to provide the flag but I get `Regex failure: undefined group option` from jq.  
- I did not find any way to set or even know if jq's Oniguruma is expecting Unicode or not, though `man jq` indicates that jq should indeed deal with Unicode.
- I searched issues on [kkos/oniguruma](https://github.com/kkos/oniguruma) but did not find anything relevant.
- I found another regex word boundary unexpected behavior: spurious empty strings when splitting a "normal" string (only a-z and space). https://jqplay.org/s/ez12mYzISR

Attached segfault report from macOS (jq called from VSCode).
[ERROR__jq_regex_segfault.txt](https://github.com/stedolan/jq/files/6327163/ERROR__jq_regex_segfault.txt)

title: [Feature] support no_color env to disable ansi_color output
body:
It would be nice to control the coloring via an environment variable. My use case is that I have `jq` running inside [wasm-terminal](https://github.com/wasmerio/wasmer-js) and would like to suppress its ansi_coloring when wasm-terminal detects that jq's input is being piped to another program (WASI's `isatty` is not supported in the browser).

I know that I can disable coloring via the  `-M` flag but it would mean I have to add a special case in wasm-terminal as opposed to `NO_COLOR` which is supported by an increasing number of CLI programs.

See https://no-color.org/

title: Use a regex to parse ISO8601 dates
body:
`strptime` is not consistently available and functional across operating systems; specifically, the code to parse timezones may or may not exist. This changes `fromdateiso8601` to support, via regexen, the two most common ISO 8601 date formats: `dateTtimeZ` and `dateTtime+00:00`, where `+00:00` is an offset from GMT (the `+` can be a `-` for the western hemisphere).

I believe this fixes bug #2195.

I am not sure if it would be desirable to also revert #1823 since that was (I believe) added specifically for `fromdateiso8601`.

title: with_entries and from_entries improvement to support array
body:
If I'm not wrong `with_entries` is made to apply filter and suppose to get the same type of data than the input.
IMHO, we should always get the same JSON type data than the input.
`with_entries` works fine with JSON object. It should be good to be able to deals with JSON array too.

## to_entries

```
- OK      {}              |to_entries == []
- OK      {"a":"A"}       |to_entries == [{key:"a",value:"A"}]
- OK      ["foo"]         |to_entries == [{key:0, value:"foo"}]
```

## from_entries

```
- OK      []                      |from_entries == {}
- OK      [{key:"a",value:"A"}]   |from_entries == {"a":"A"}
- FIXED   [{key:0, value:"foo"}]  |from_entries == ["foo"]
- ??      ???                     |from_entries          == []  # impossible, not supported
- FIXED   []                      |from_entries("array") == []  # solution
```

## with_entries(.)

```
- OK      {}              |with_entries(.) == {}
- OK      {"a":"A"}       |with_entries(.) == {"a":"A"}
- FIXED   ["a"]           |with_entries(.) == ["a"]
- FIXED   []              |with_entries(.) == []
``` 


See below my first version:

```jq
def from_entries($type):
        if $type=="array" then
                map(select(.key // .Key // .name // .Name >=0)) | map(if has("value") then .value elif has("Value") then .Value else empty end)
        else
                map({(.key // .Key // .name // .Name): (if has("value") then .value else .Value end)}) | add | .//={}
        end
;

def from_entries:
        if .[0].key|type=="number" then
                from_entries("array")
        else
                from_entries("object")
        end
;

def with_entries(f):
        type as $type |
        to_entries | map(f) | from_entries($type)
;
```

See my second version is more compact, see my PR https://github.com/stedolan/jq/pull/2293

title: Bump jinja2 from 2.10 to 2.11.3 in /docs

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps [jinja2](https://github.com/pallets/jinja) from 2.10 to 2.11.3.
Release notes

Sourced from jinja2's releases.

2.11.3

This contains a fix for a speed issue with the urlize filter. urlize is likely to be called on untrusted user input. For certain inputs some of the regular expressions used to parse the text could take a very long time due to backtracking. As part of the fix, the email matching became slightly stricter. The various speedups apply to urlize in general, not just the specific input cases.

  • PyPI: https://pypi.org/project/Jinja2/2.11.3/
  • Changes: https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.11.x/changelog/#version-2-11-3

2.11.2

  • Changelog: https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.11.x/changelog/#version-2-11-2

2.11.1

This fixes an issue in async environment when indexing the result of an attribute lookup, like {{ data.items[1:] }}.

  • Changes: https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.11.x/changelog/#version-2-11-1

2.11.0

  • Changes: https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.11.x/changelog/#version-2-11-0
  • Blog: https://palletsprojects.com/blog/jinja-2-11-0-released/
  • Twitter: https://twitter.com/PalletsTeam/status/1221883554537230336

This is the last version to support Python 2.7 and 3.5. The next version will be Jinja 3.0 and will support Python 3.6 and newer.

2.10.3

  • Changes: http://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.10.x/changelog/#version-2-10-3

2.10.2

  • Changes: http://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.10.x/changelog/#version-2-10-2

2.10.1

  • Changes: https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/2.10.x/changelog/#version-2-10-1
  • Blog: https://palletsprojects.com/blog/jinja-2-10-1-released/
  • Twitter: https://twitter.com/PalletsTeam/status/1114605127308992513
Changelog

Sourced from jinja2's changelog.

Version 2.11.3

Released 2021-01-31

  • Improve the speed of the urlize filter by reducing regex backtracking. Email matching requires a word character at the start of the domain part, and only word characters in the TLD. :pr:1343

Version 2.11.2

Released 2020-04-13

  • Fix a bug that caused callable objects with __getattr__, like :class:~unittest.mock.Mock to be treated as a :func:contextfunction. :issue:1145
  • Update wordcount filter to trigger :class:Undefined methods by wrapping the input in :func:soft_str. :pr:1160
  • Fix a hang when displaying tracebacks on Python 32-bit. :issue:1162
  • Showing an undefined error for an object that raises AttributeError on access doesn't cause a recursion error. :issue:1177
  • Revert changes to :class:~loaders.PackageLoader from 2.10 which removed the dependency on setuptools and pkg_resources, and added limited support for namespace packages. The changes caused issues when using Pytest. Due to the difficulty in supporting Python 2 and :pep:451 simultaneously, the changes are reverted until 3.0. :pr:1182
  • Fix line numbers in error messages when newlines are stripped. :pr:1178
  • The special namespace() assignment object in templates works in async environments. :issue:1180
  • Fix whitespace being removed before tags in the middle of lines when lstrip_blocks is enabled. :issue:1138
  • :class:~nativetypes.NativeEnvironment doesn't evaluate intermediate strings during rendering. This prevents early evaluation which could change the value of an expression. :issue:1186

Version 2.11.1

Released 2020-01-30

  • Fix a bug that prevented looking up a key after an attribute ({{ data.items[1:] }}) in an async template. :issue:1141

title: Error selecting values using paths(node_filter)
body:
<!--
READ THIS FIRST!

If you have a usage question, please ask us on either Stack Overflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jq) or in the #jq channel (http://irc.lc/freenode/%23jq/) on Freenode (https://webchat.freenode.net/).

-->

**Describe the bug**
Was trying to delete all null objects/values from my JSON, but using the `paths(node_filter)` function to generate their paths was unsuccessful.

**To Reproduce**
Using an example from the Docs, and filter as used on jqplay (using // for comment just over here)

    Input : [[],{},1,"foo",null,true,false]
    paths(nulls) // Empty o/p -
    paths(nulls | not) // o/p - [4]
    paths(values) // o/p - [0, 1, 2, 3, 5]
    paths(values | not) // o/p - [6]
    paths(booleans) // o/p - [5]
    paths(booleans | not) // o/p - [6]
    paths(. == null) // o/p - [4] | filter is similar to nulls but this works unlike nulls

The same issue seems to extend to all other `node_filter` it seems, since only true values are produced, for `scalar`, and false or null values, for `scalar | not`.

**Expected behavior**
For any given pre-defined `node_filter` the output should consist of the values satisfying them.

    Input : [[],{},1,"foo",null,true,false]
    paths(nulls) // Expected o/p - [4]
    paths(nulls | not) // o/p - [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6]
    paths(values) // o/p - [0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 6]
    paths(values | not) // o/p - [4]
    paths(booleans) // o/p - [5, 6]
    paths(booleans | not) // o/p - [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
    paths(. == null) // o/p - [4] | filter is now similar to nulls

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS and Version:
   - Windows 10 (WSL2 Ubuntu 20.04)
   - Linux
     - Ubuntu 20.04
     - Mint 19.3
 - jq version - 1.6

title: Add in-place modification (expression) shorthand in objects
body:
Just as `{"a": .a}` is shortened into `{a}`, I shortened `{"a": .a | expr}` into `{a | expr}`.  
This is unambiguous because `jq` doesn't accept bare expressions inside object definitions.

I added tests and a paragraph in the manual, let me know if it's not clear enough (I'm not a native speaker).  
Thank you for the awesome project :D

## Comparisons

### Selecting and modifying specific fields

The syntax stays consistent between selection and in-place processing

```sh
# Before:
echo '{"title": "Hello", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}' | ./jq '{foo, "title": .title | ascii_upcase}'
# After:
echo '{"title": "Hello", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}' | ./jq '{foo, title | ascii_upcase}'
# Output:
# {"foo": 1, "title": "HELLO"}
```

### Modifying specific fields (patching)

Variant 1: Works better when modifying a value nested deeply in `.`
Variant 2: Increases focus on the expression itself, by removing the "noisy" syntax (`"a": .a`)

```sh
# Before:
echo '{"title": "Hello", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}' | ./jq '.title |= ascii_upcase'
echo '{"title": "Hello", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}' | ./jq '. + {"title": .title | ascii_upcase}'
# After:
echo '{"title": "Hello", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}' | ./jq '. + {title | ascii_upcase}'
# Output:
# {"title": "HELLO", "foo": 1, "bar": 2}
```

### Nested selection

It now resembles GraphQL queries, which are familiar to many devs, which should reduce the learning curve for them.

```sh
# Before:
echo '{"hello": {"world": {"foo": 1, "bar": 2}, "there": 3}, "misc": 4}' | ./jq '{"hello": .hello | {"world": .world | {foo}, there}}'
echo '{"hello": {"world": {"foo": 1, "bar": 2}, "there": 3}, "misc": 4}' | ./jq '{"hello": {"world": {"foo": .hello.world.foo}, "there": .hello.there}'
# After:
echo '{"hello": {"world": {"foo": 1, "bar": 2}, "there": 3}, "misc": 4}' | ./jq '{hello | {world | {foo}, there}}'
# Output:
# {"hello": {"world": {"foo": 1}, "there": 3}}
```

title: Error code = 0 on parse error
body:
```
% jq --version
jq-1.6
```

Error code is non-zero on parse error as expected:
```
% echo "a" | jq -R 'select(input_line_number<=1)|tonumber'; echo $?
jq: error (at <stdin>:1): Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 1 (while parsing 'a')
5
```

jq swallows the error if the next item is filtered out.
```
% echo "a\nb" | jq -R 'select(input_line_number<=1)|tonumber'; echo $?
jq: error (at <stdin>:1): Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 1 (while parsing 'a')
0
```

Is there a way to reliably get a nonzero error code when jq throws any error message at me without parsing stderr?

title: Document difference between expanding to an array or to an object using an 'if' statement.
body:
Hi,

I'm not sure if this is a bug, or whether it should just be documented as a "Pitfall".
I was quite confused by it, but perhaps it is because I'm relatively new to jq. I couldn't find any documentation on it perhaps I missed it, or was searching for wrong keywords ...

The input is a line, from a log:
```
{
  "date": "2021/02/25 11:14:59",
  "FRITZ!DECT 301 #3": {
    "name": "FRITZ!DECT 301 #3",
    "battery": "30",
    ....
  }
}

```
I want to see the date and the "battery" status, which is produced as strings with the following filter:
[(.date) , .[].battery?](https://jqplay.org/s/m2dr0MvjLa)

Suppose we want to return it as an array we would change it too:
[[(.date) , .[].battery? ]](https://jqplay.org/s/-07JwNNdis)
Or as an object:
[{(.date) : .[].battery? }](https://jqplay.org/s/JOZp_fkeIW)

I wanted to use an if statement, instead of the '?' construct, so first for the array output, which works fine:
[[ .[] | if type == "object" then .battery else . end ]](https://jqplay.org/s/z_hkAB-B99)
Here the confusion started when I tried to output an object, as my first attempt, changing '[' to '}' brackets, gave a compile error:
[{ .[] | if type == "object" then .battery else . end }](https://jqplay.org/s/Pm_2tHuzAg)

After quite some research the following seemed to be the correct way to generate an object:
[{ (.date) : (.[] | if type == "object" then  .battery  else empty end) }](https://jqplay.org/s/lNXdAS_FP8) 

So while implicit expanding to an array works fine with an 'if' construct, it fails for expanding to an object. Only when we explicitly force it to the ":" format the output succeeds. The "asymmetry" is unexpected, at least by me :-), and I think  should be documented or perhaps if possible repaired. The man page and its examples, do seems to "state" that the {,} and [,] constructs are symmetric. Of course the problem arises here because we need {:}, which is also in the '{}' manual topic.

p.s. Big fan of jq! Great how it e.g. allows to handle complex data structures in 'bash' by storing "json" data in shell variables...

title: Multiple consecutive newlines are causing memory error and crash with --raw-input

title: Namespace behavior of nested includes
body:
**Describe the bug**

The `include` [documentation](https://stedolan.github.io/jq/manual/v1.6/#includeRelativePathString[%3Cmetadata%3E];) say:
> **`include RelativePathString [\<metadata\>];`**
>
> Imports a module found at the given path relative to a directory in a search path as if it were included in place. A ".jq" suffix will be added to the relative path string. The module's symbols are imported into the caller's namespace as if the module's content had been included directly.

Accodrding to this, when an included module includes another module, the expectation is that the symbols of both mudules are included in the top-level namespace:
1. The namespace of the outer include contains the symbols of the inner include as if it had been included directly
2. Similarly, the combined symbols become part of the top-level namespace.

However, it seems like the top-level namespace includes only the symbols of the outer include.

**To Reproduce**

- Create `outer.jq` containing
  
  ```
   include "inner";
   ```
- Create `inner.jq` containing
  
  ```
   def test: true;
   ```
- `echo 1 | jq "include \"inner\"; test"` produces the expected result:
  
   ```
   true
   ```
- `echo 1 | jq "include \"outer\"; test"` produces an error:
  
   ```
   jq: error: test/0 is not defined at <top-level>, line 1:
   include "outer";test
   jq: 1 compile error
   ```

**Expected behavior**
Both runs are expected to produce
  
```
true
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS and Version: windows 10 Pro
 - jq version: 1.6

**Additional context**

If this is by design, please clarify the bahavior of nested includes in the docuentation. In particular, is it possible to access the symbols of the nested include?

If the symbols of the nested include are not accessible from the top-level, then the `include` statement has two effects:
1. The outer include becomes part of the top-level.
2. The outer include serves as a firewall preventing access to nested includes.

title: Add comparison / tip guide for JMESPath and jp tool
body:
I see there's a wiki page for tips and a comparison of jq to JSONPath: https://github.com/stedolan/jq/wiki/For-JSONPath-users

[JMESPath](https://jmespath.org) seems to be a recent new alternative option for querying JSON, and adopted by some key organizations like Amazon and Microsoft. And there's a command line tool version called [jp](https://github.com/jmespath/jp).

It might be worthwhile to do a similar page for that. This too could be a community contribution from anyone wanting to document this.

title: @base64d does not handle web-safe encoded base64
body:
**Describe the bug**
Many programs output "web safe" or "filename safe" base64 (defined in [RFC 4648](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4648#section-5) and called `base64url`).  In this format the `/` and `+` characters are replaced with `_` and `-`, and the `=` padding is often URI escaped with `%3D`.  The `@base64d` string formatter does not handle this variant.

**To Reproduce**

```
$ echo '_-8%3D' | jq -R -r '@base64d'
jq: error (at <stdin>:1): string ("_-%3D") is not valid base64 data
```

**Expected behavior**

```
$ echo '_-8%3D' | jq -R -r '@base64d' | xxd -g1
00000000: ff ef
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Ubuntu 20.04.
 - jq-1.6

**Additional context**
Having a way to output the raw binary would be helpful, too.  The `@base64d` does not output the two bytes `0xFF 0xFE`, but instead does a UTF-8 expansion.

title: uri decode function
body:
**Describe the bug**
The `@uri` string formatter percent-escapes it's input, but there is no filter to reverse the process.

**To Reproduce**
```
$ echo '"="' | jq -r '@uri'
%3D
```
It seems that perhaps `@text` would convert it back, but it passes the string unmodified:
```
$ echo '%3D' | jq -R -r '@text'
%3D
```

**Expected behavior**
That there would be a `@urid` or similar to match `@base64` / `@base64d`.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
- Ubuntu LInux 20.04
 - jq version 1.6

title: Improved list destructuring by adding a 'rest' operator
body:
**Describe the request**

I am trying to work with list destructuring. I want to be able to destructure array-like types (eg. array, string) into 'head' and 'tail' parts.

This is what I've been doing so far:
```sh
def head: .[0:1] | select(length >0) | if type == "array" then .[] else . end;
def tail: .[1:];
```

```sh
{ head: head, tail: tail }
```

This works for destructuring both strings and arrays.

**Expected behavior**

* Either include above two functions into the builtin.jq or
* Support destructuring with  a 'rest' operator (similar to how [javascript destructuring can use the rest operator](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/Destructuring_assignment) or how [python3 is using the starred expression](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3132/) to do it.

The operator one I would imagine to look like something in javascript, like `...`:

```sh
echo "[1,2,3,4,5]" | jq '. as [$head, ...$tail] | {$head, $tail}
[
  1,
  [
    2,
    3,
    4,
    5
  ]
]
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS and Version: macOS
 - jq version 1.6

title: UTF8 data corruption read from stdin (erroneous substitution by U+FFFD)
body:
**Describe the bug**
jq replaces some valid utf8 characters read from stdin by U+FFFD (internally and in its output).

**To Reproduce**
There is no U+FFFD in the stdin:
`cat test_raw.txt | grep 'ÔøΩ'`
But there are U+FFFD characters in the output:
`cat test_raw.txt | jq --raw-input --raw-output '.' | grep 'ÔøΩ'`

[test_raw.txt](https://github.com/stedolan/jq/files/5899513/test_raw.txt)

- as I understand '–Å' characters in the example file can be replaced with any multi-byte character and issue will be still reproducible
- it is required to use a string with length greater than jq reading buffer size (4096) to reproduce the issue

**Expected behavior**
jq keeps strings as it is.
In the specified case, produces the same results as the command below (reading not from stdin, but from file):
`jq --null-input --raw-output '$f | .' --rawfile f test_raw.txt | grep 'ÔøΩ'`

**Environment:**
 - Arch Linux
 - jq version 1.6

**Additional notes**

Looks like the same issue was fixed for reading from files: https://github.com/stedolan/jq/commit/e84d17196c03da6e6dc56f4fcd319a7fe84f8dbc

As I found, wrong characters replacing occurs here: https://github.com/stedolan/jq/blob/master/src/util.c:
value = jv_string_concat(value, **jv_string_sized(state->buf, state->buf_valid_len)**);
state->buf[0] = '\0';
state->buf_valid_len = 0;

Probably, jq_util_read_more function reads only part of the utf8 character to the buffer (truncation by the 4096 buffer size leads to incomplete character reading).

title: Alternative storage default options
body:
This issue is intended to be used as a discussion.

We've had users that, through automation, have created a couple hundred 1k release secrets. A couple applications in the cluster poll secrets (grumble) and when those polls happened to stack up, and the api server couldn't serve the request from cache, the list queries are individually sent to etcd which cannot filter the lookup. Etcd can only respond with all the secrets in the namespace (or all secrets if the query is not namespaced). These queries can take some time to read and confirm consensus. When the etcd responses start timing out, this perfect storm starts to happen and the control-plane ends up in a deadlock.

This issue is to discuss other ideas on how to solve this starvation with a different default store.

Keep in mind, that the goal of the default store is that it be usable by a user with less-than-admin rights. Maybe not able to create CRDs, maybe no StorageClasses. This should be solvable using only namespaced native resources.

title: Fix `--indent 0` implicitly enabling compact-output
body: Now it will retain pretty-printing, just removing any indentation. See also https://github.com/stedolan/jq/issues/1465.

title: Added a first fuzzer for integration with OSS-Fuzz.
body:
Hi Maintainers,

I would like to set up continuous fuzzing of jq by way of OSS-Fuzz. Essentially, OSS-Fuzz is a free service run by Google that performs continuous fuzzing of important open source projects. The only expectation of integrating into OSS-Fuzz is that bugs will be fixed. This is not a "hard" requirement in that no one enforces this and the main point is if bugs are not fixed then it is a waste of resources to run the fuzzers, which we would like to avoid.

In this PR https://github.com/google/oss-fuzz/pull/4980 I have done exactly that, namely created the necessary logic from an OSS-Fuzz perspective to integrate jq. If you would like to integrate, could you please provide a set of email(s) that will get access to the data produced by OSS-Fuzz, such as bug reports, coverage reports and more stats. The emails should be linked to a Google account in order to view the detailed reports and notice the emails affiliated with the project will be public in the OSS-Fuzz repo, as they will be part of a configuration file.

title: Fix number lexer to avoid conflict with object indexing
body:
This fixes #1526, #1651.
Currently jq does not correctly handle indexing like `.e0`. It tries to parse as numeric literal even if it does not accept it. I fixed the lexer to consider `.e0` (and alike; `.E1`, `.E-1`) as object indexing, not invalid numeric literal.
```
 % echo '{"e0": 1, "E1": 2, "E": 3}' | jq '.e0, .E1, .E-1, .E+1'
jq: error: Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 3 (while parsing '.e0') at <top-level>, line 1:
.e0, .E1, .E-1, .E+1
jq: error: Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 3 (while parsing '.E1') at <top-level>, line 1:
.e0, .E1, .E-1, .E+1
jq: error: Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '.E-1') at <top-level>, line 1:
.e0, .E1, .E-1, .E+1
jq: error: Invalid numeric literal at EOF at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '.E+1') at <top-level>, line 1:
.e0, .E1, .E-1, .E+1
jq: 4 compile errors
```

title: Make 0 divided by 0 results in NaN consistently
body:
`0/0` is folded to `nan` on parsing but `0 as $x | $x/0` throws a zero-division error so `0/0` is not equal to `0 as $x | $x/0`. This is not intuitive. I think `0 as $x | $x/0` should be `nan` as well as `0/0` is.
```
 % jq -n '0/0, (0 as $x | $x/0) | isnan'
true
jq: error (at <unknown>): number (0) and number (0) cannot be divided because the divisor is zero
```

title: Fold modulo operator on constant values and raise zero remainder error quickly
body: Currently constant division is folded on parsing and zero division raises `Division by zero?` error quickly. There is `Remainder by zero?` error message found in `parser.y` but this will never be thrown because `constant_fold` does not fold the modulo operator. So I added folding on constant modulo and make `jq -n "1%0"` throws the `Remainder by zero?` error and exits with `3` (just like `jq -n "1/0"`). The infinity is caught by [`block_is_const_inf`](https://github.com/stedolan/jq/blob/a17dd3248a666d01be75f6b16be37e80e20b0954/src/parser.y#L464-L468). Returning infinity here may look wired (zero modulo is not infinity) but it applies to division as well; zero division in jq is not infinity but it's ok because the infinity is filtered out by `block_is_const_inf`. This follows the commit b9c2a326bae085a27b5bd01ca15c3c42c7b726a3.

title: Enhance @sh to output objects as bash associative array initialisers
body:
Bash allows associative arrays to be initialised using declarations of
the form

  name=([foo]=1 [bar]=42 [baz]="hello")

At present, the @sh filter can format arrays into space-separated
strings:

```
$ ip -j addr | jq -c -r '.[] | {ifname, addr_info: .addr_info[]} | {ifname, family: .addr_info["family"], address: .addr_info["local"]} | [.[]] | @sh' | head -n 3
'lo' 'inet' '127.0.0.1'
'lo' 'inet6' '::1'
'eth0' 'inet' '93.93.131.233'
```

We alter the @sh filter to output objects as well, in a
format suitable for use as bash associative array initialisers:

```
$ ip -j addr | jq -c -r '.[] | {ifname, addr_info: .addr_info[]} | {ifname, family: .addr_info["family"], address: .addr_info["local"]} | @sh' | head -n 3
[ifname]='lo' [family]='inet' [address]='127.0.0.1'
[ifname]='lo' [family]='inet6' [address]='::1'
[ifname]='eth0' [family]='inet' [address]='93.93.131.233'
```

Allowing us to use symbolic names to reference values:

```
$ ip -j addr | jq -c -r '.[] | {ifname, addr_info: .addr_info[]} | {ifname, family: .addr_info["family"], address: .addr_info["local"]} | @sh' | while read initialiser; do declare -A iface; eval iface=($initialiser); echo "Interface ${iface[ifname]} has ${iface[family]} address ${iface[address]}"; done | head -n 3
Interface lo has inet address 127.0.0.1
Interface lo has inet6 address ::1
Interface eth0 has inet address 93.93.131.233
```

title: What's the simplest way to _iterate_ over a JSON array using `for` or `while`?
body:
What's the simplest way to _iterate_ over a JSON array using `for` or `while`? 

The documentation doesn't provide simple examples of such iteration using jq

Given this simple JSON:

```
{
    "users": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "description": "alfred one",
            "admin": true,
            "height": 10
        },
        {
            "id": 2,
            "description": "alice two",
            "admin": true,
            "height": 11
        },
        {
            "id": 3,
            "description": "emma three",
            "admin": false,
            "height": 33
        }
    ]
}
```

How can I perform an operation over each object in the array? 

For example, just concatenate strings thus:
```
alfred one is 10
alice two is 11
emma three is 33
```

I tried this:

```
for i in "$(jq -r '.users[]' users.json)"; do
    name=$(echo $i | jq -r .description)
    height=$(echo $i | jq -r .height)
    echo "$name has id $height" 
done
```

But this produces this:

```
alfred one
alice two
emma three is 10
11
33
```

(I may be able to use `join` in this specific instance, but that's besides the point, I am asking for a generic solution to use jq in while and for loops)

Also consider updating the documentation accordingly, this has caused some confusion in the past (see https://github.com/stedolan/jq/issues/2169 and https://github.com/stedolan/jq/issues/1137)

title: Incorrect result of input_line_number function
body:
<!--
READ THIS FIRST!

If you have a usage question, please ask us on either Stack Overflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jq) or in the #jq channel (http://irc.lc/freenode/%23jq/) on Freenode (https://webchat.freenode.net/).

-->

**Describe the bug**
The `input_line_number` function yields an incorrect result when the length of the line is multiple of 4095.

**To Reproduce**
```bash
# 4093 + 2 quote = 4095
$ python3 -c "print('0\n\"' + 'a'*4093 + '\"\n0');" | jq 'input_line_number'
1
1
3

# 16378 + 2 quote = 4095 * 4
$ python3 -c "print('0\n\"' + 'a'*16378 + '\"\n0');" | jq 'input_line_number'
1
1
3
```

**Expected behavior**
```bash
1
2
3
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - Arch Linux
 - jq-1.6

**Additional context**
We only increase the counter only when the current buffer contains a newline character.
https://github.com/stedolan/jq/blob/master/src/util.c#L313

title: Added base/1 and unbase/1
body:
Base conversion functions get re-implemented quite frequently, thus they deserve their own built-ins.

`base/1` takes an operand `x` and converts the input to base `x`. Example usage:
```
14 | base(2)  -> [1, 1, 1, 0]
```

`unbase/1` is the opposite of `base/1`: it takes an operand `x` and converts the input from base `x`. Example usage:
```
[1, 1, 1, 0] | unbase(2) -> 14
```

title: The number syntax in jq is different from JavaScript
body:
**Describe the bug**
[The manual](https://github.com/stedolan/jq/blob/80052e5275ae8c45b20411eecdd49c945a64a412/docs/content/manual/manual.yml#L521-L522) says that numbers in the jq language are written the same way as in JavaScript, but this is not the case. 

**To Reproduce**
jq fails to parse the numeric literal separator:
```
$ node -p '123_456'
123456
$ jq -n '123_456'
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
123_456   
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse binary, octal and hexadecimal literals:
```
$ node -p '0b111'; node -p '0o111'; node -p '0x111'
7
73
273
$ jq -n '0b111'; jq -n '0o111'; jq -n '0x111'
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
0b111 
jq: 1 compile error
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
0o111 
jq: 1 compile error
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected IDENT, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
0x111 
jq: 1 compile error
```

**Expected behavior**
The misleading documentation should be changed.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
```
$ jq --version
jq-1.6
$ cat /etc/fedora-release 
Fedora release 32 (Thirty Two)
```

**Additional context**
https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-literals-numeric-literals

title: The string syntax in jq is different from JavaScript
body:
**Describe the bug**
[The manual](https://github.com/stedolan/jq/blob/80052e5275ae8c45b20411eecdd49c945a64a412/docs/content/manual/manual.yml#L521-L522) says that strings in the jq language are written the same way as in JavaScript, but this is not the case. 

**To Reproduce**
jq fails to parse single quoted strings:
```
$ node -p "'foo'"
foo
$ jq -n "'foo'"
jq: error: syntax error, unexpected INVALID_CHARACTER, expecting $end (Unix shell quoting issues?) at <top-level>, line 1:
'foo'
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse \XXX octal escapes:
```
$ node -p '"\101"'
A
$ jq -n '"\101"'
jq: error: Invalid escape at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '"\1"') at <top-level>, line 1:
"\101" 
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse the \' escape:
```
$ node -p \"\\\'\"
'
$ jq -n \"\\\'\"
jq: error: Invalid escape at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '"\'"') at <top-level>, line 1:
"\'" 
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse the \v escape
```
$ node -p '"\v"'


$ jq -n '"\v"'
jq: error: Invalid escape at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '"\v"') at <top-level>, line 1:
"\v" 
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse \u{X} ... \u{XXXXXX} escapes:
```
$ node -p '"\u{41}"'
A
$ jq -n '"\u{41}"'
jq: error: Invalid \uXXXX escape at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '"\u"') at <top-level>, line 1:
"\u{41}" 
jq: 1 compile error
```

jq fails to parse \xXX escapes
```
$ node -p '"\x41"'
A
$ jq -n '"\x41"'
jq: error: Invalid escape at line 1, column 4 (while parsing '"\x"') at <top-level>, line 1:
"\x41" 
jq: 1 compile error
```

The list above is probably not exhaustive.

**Expected behavior**
The misleading documentation should be changed.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
```
$ jq --version
jq-1.6
$ cat /etc/fedora-release 
Fedora release 32 (Thirty Two)
```

**Additional context**
The js string syntax is described here: https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-literals-string-literals

title: Feature Request: a THIS operator for structure indices
body:
Hi there.

First a big thank you for an invaluable tool!

Imagine if you will, you get some data like:
`{
    "Maps": [
        {
            "Value": "1", 
            "Key": "A"
        }, 
        {
            "Value": "2", 
            "Key": "B"
        }, 
        {
            "Value": "3", 
            "Key": "C"
        }
    ]
}`

Do something like:  `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[0].Key): .[0].Value, (.[1].Key): .[1].Value, (.[2].Key): .[2].Value}'`

Your desired output in this case is:

`{
    "A": "1",
    "B": "2",
    "C": "3",
}`

Instead, I suggest an operator like `THIS`:  `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[!].Key): .[!].Value}'`

**[EDIT]**
_An offset would work similarly:_  `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[!+1].Key): .[!].Value}'`

`{
    "B": "1",
    "C": "2",
    "A": "3",
}`

_This is based on the modification of the indices not the data elements._
**[/EDIT]**

When we look at: `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[].Key): .[].Value}'` the output is as expected:
`{
    "A": "1",
    "A": "2",
    "A": "3",
    "B": "1",
    "B": "2",
    "B": "3",
    "C": "1",
    "C": "2",
    "C": "3",
}`

This would again be the same expected result for:  `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[!].Key): .[].Value}'` and `echo $sampled | jq -s '.[].Maps|{(.[].Key): .[!].Value}'` .

The purpose of the `THIS` operator would be to select two or more elements at the same level in a structure with matching `THIS` operators.

**WARNING** Bonus Feature Extension
Speculatively, this semantic might tenuously lend itself to a `FOR` like operation?  I'm reaching here but hear me out, please.

`jq --lda lamda "echo ${sampled} | jq -s '.[].Maps[!].Value'" -r '.[]' <(web-api --id $lambda)`

I realise that this is really stretching things, maybe a bit too far.  I'm expecting to hear the snap at any moment.

The way that I imagine this would work. The primary jq instance in lambda mode would set an environmental variable as named by the label after the flag.  The lambda instance steps through its data structure where the `THIS` operator occurs. Each step returning the result to the named variable (without the `THIS` operator the lambda instance would only have one step).  The primary calling jq instance runs for that step and append its result set to its final output.  The lambda operation only completing once the lambda instance has exhausted its data structure.

Another term other than lambda may be more appropriate?

Equivalent to bash:
`for row in $(echo "$sampled" | jq -sr '.[].Maps[].Value') ; do`
`      jq -s '.[]' <(web-api id=$row);`
`done`

Thank you for taking the time read this.


Respectfully,

Stephen.

title: `fromdateiso8601` doesn't support the "decimal fraction" component in time values.
body:
**Describe the bug**
The [ISO8601 time format](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Times) supports a decimal fraction attached to the smallest component present; this is passably common for seconds to represent micro- or nano-seconds.  Technically this is also applicable to the minute and hour components, though I have never seen that used in the wild.

`fromdateiso8601` doesn't handle fractional seconds, which is an annoyance since I have several JSON applications that emit them, and where I'd like to do some date comparisons.

**To Reproduce**
```shell
] jq -nr '"2020-12-11T01:00:52.605001Z" | fromdateiso8601'
jq: error (at <unknown>): date "2020-12-11T01:00:52.605001Z" does not match format "%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%SZ"
```

**Expected behavior**
`jq(1)` would parse fractional seconds; ideally, it would also carry and emit them, but just ignoring the fraction would be sufficient for my needs.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - macOS 10.15.7 x64
 - `jq-1.6`

**Additional context**
This is definitely an extension on the basic POSIX time functions, so perhaps isn't interesting to jq.  I'd hope it was, since they are fairly commonly used, but I understand if this is bounced as "not interested".

title: Default search path / module-load somewhat broken in jq 1.6
body:
Running under debian 8 (jessie) and Ubuntu focal (20.04.1) with jq-linux64 1.6.

Having a devil of a time getting modules to load from a centralized location.  I'm using file ~/.jq as a default module for "always" functions, so it's not possible to put loadables in ~/.jq/

I have noted performance behavior that differs from what is stated or suggested in the documentation under Modules:

> The default search path is the search path given to the -L command-line option, else ["~/.jq", "$ORIGIN/../lib/jq", "$ORIGIN/../lib"].

I find this not to be the case, at least with regard to the third.  jq -n 'get_search_list' returns:

> [
>   "~/.jq",
>   "$ORIGIN/../lib/jq",
>   "$ORIGIN/lib"
> ]

Also, the following from Modules is either wrong or quite misleading:

> For paths starting with "$ORIGIN/", the path of the jq executable is substituted for "$ORIGIN".

My jq executable is located at /usr/bin, which is in my $PATH, so I invoke it with simply "jq".  As a result, jq returns the following values for 'get_jq_origin' and 'get_prog_origin':

> "."
> "/forms"

(The second, /forms, was my cwd at the time.)

So, at least in this environment with this version of jq, the only remotely concrete location that could be used by default for a library of modules is ~/.jq/ -- which eliminates the possibility of automatically loading a module by default upon every invocation, which is very important to me.  Under the circumstances, $ORIGIN is useless if it only takes an explicit path from the command line and not the ultimate found location of the binary, which seems to be what was intended....

Finally, the way that 'import' and 'include' have been written to use only RelativePath precludes (in every attempt I have made) trying to indicate an absolute path for the module, in favor of "helping" me by using a broken search-path scheme.  This leaves as about the only alternative using an explicit -L to point at my module library on every invocation of jq -- of course I could alias that in, but aliases are not usually set in non-interactive shell invocations of scripts, raising a whole extra level of inconvenience and inconsistent operation/invocation depending on runtime context.

If I'm missing some really simple solution(s), I'd love for someone to make me feel foolish and point it out.

Thanks for reading.  At some point, if I can find the time, I'm going to try to dig up some source for this and see if I can figure out how to fix it, but my C-fu is a little rusty....

-Mike B

title: Fix strflocaltime on daylight saving time values
body:
This PR changes the way time values get serialised and deserialised to the internal format when passing them between stages. Previously the internal value didn't retain the dst value so time values would lose that field and when printed using `strflocaltime`, the fact the value was in DST was lost. This seems to me to be the only way to have `strflocaltime` printing the correct time zone information on values during a daylight saving time.

The following behaviour demonstrates how the daylight savings value gets
lost when a time value gets turned into an internal array of numbers and
then back into a (struct tm):

        $ TZ=Europe/London ./jq -r -n '1504803635 | strflocaltime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S (%Z)")'
        2017-09-07 18:00:35 (GMT)

After this change however, this works as expected:

        $ TZ=Europe/London ./jq -r -n '1504803635 | strflocaltime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S (%Z)")'
        2017-09-07 18:00:35 (BST)

(the only difference is in the `%Z` value - "BST" instead of the incorrect "GMT").

title: strptime/1 ignores ISO-8601 TimeZone (format string "%z")
Behaviour in "jq play 1,6" different from announced in the manual for jq 1.6
body:
**Describe the bug**
The results obtained when clicking the Run button in page 

https://stedolan.github.io/jq/manual/v1.6/#Identity:.

are not the expected ones. The example says that running (in _jq play 1.6_) the code

```
jq '. as $big \| [$big, $big + 1] \| map(. > 10000000000000000000000000000000)'
```
using as input

```
10000000000000000000000000000001
```

gives the results:

```
[true, false]
```

but those aren't the real results. The real ones are:

```
[
  false,
  false
]
```





**To Reproduce**

You can reproduce going to https://jqplay.org/s/w_W5hg3mb0

The original URL for jqplay is:

https://jqplay.org/jq?q=.%20as%20%24big%20%7C%20%5B%24big%2C%20%24big%20%2B%201%5D%20%7C%20map(.%20%3E%2010000000000000000000000000000000)&j=10000000000000000000000000000001

I think that in the example it should changed the values of input and the one used to compare, to have something like this:

https://jqplay.org/s/ihmde54MIC

that ejecutes

```
. as $big | [$big, $big + 1] | map(. > 1000000000000000)
```

with input `1000000000000000`.

This gives the result:

```
[
  false,
  true
]
```

But if you add an addition `0` to both the comparison and the input, the response changes to

```
[
  false,
  false
]
```

that seems to indicate that comparing big numbers doesn't work properly, as you can see in https://jqplay.org/s/Cmg74fPKy-


**Expected behavior**
I think that the expected values are wrong, but that the example in the actual state doesn't do what it was intented for.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - jq play version 1.6 online: https://jqplay.org/s/w_W5hg3mb0

title: Alternative operator // applied on a stream
body:
Hi,

I'm getting a result which doesn't seem logical to me, considering the documented behavior of the alternative operator `//`.

Excerpt from the manual:
> A filter of the form a // b produces the same results as a, if a produces results other than false and null.

Here are the test commands.
```
$ jq -n 'false, 1, null, 2 | . // 0'
0
1
0
2

$ jq -n '(false, 1, null, 2) // 0'
1
2
```

The first result is ok. For the second command, I would expect either the same result as the first one, or the complete stream `false, 1, null, 2` as is (if the jq grammar defined the operator `//` to apply to a stream as a whole). Instead of one of these two options, here the output is an altered form of the left-hand side. Tested with jq 1.5, 1.6 and master (on Linux Mint 19.3).

If it's not a bug then wouldn't it be worth mentionning it in the manual?

title: Add Windows installation via scoop
body:
Extended Windows installation documentation. Now we can install the latest `jq` version via scoop (https://scoop/sh).
The scoop installation manifest is automatically updated (thx to https://github.com/ScoopInstaller/Main/commit/ea40037413ac64752be74c8ff14de352bd4e45bc) to refer to the latest `jq` version each time new scoop release appears on GH.

title: Release multi-arch stedolan/jq image
body:
I can see that there are some discussions about Dockerfile modification for stedolan/jq image - https://github.com/stedolan/jq/pull/2004

I'd like to ask to extend this work and build multi-arch image with support for at least s390x, ppc64le and arm64 architectures.

Travis which is used as CI tool for this repo has [build-in native hardware](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/multi-cpu-architectures/) for all mentioned architectures and current Travis workflow can be extended to build corresponding images and create manifest to release multi-arch image.

title: jq does not pretty print when output is not a terminal
body:
if I do :

echo file.json | jq .

I get a formatted (pretty printed) version of the json contained in the file.

But if I do:

VAR=`echo file.json | jq .`
echo $VAR

then the output stored in $VAR is not pretty-printed.

title: @tsv format string escaping
body:
<!--
READ THIS FIRST!

If you have a usage question, please ask us on either Stack Overflow (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/jq) or in the #jq channel (http://irc.lc/freenode/%23jq/) on Freenode (https://webchat.freenode.net/).

-->

**Describe the bug**
I think there's a problem with the output of single quote (apostrophe) from `... | [@sh] | @tsv `. It is escaped as if the entire output string were in double quotes.

**To Reproduce**

```
#!/bin/sh
{ json=$(cat); } <<'HERE'
{"ls":["O'Neill","d'oh"]}
HERE
printf '%s\n' "${json}" | jq -r '.[] | [@sh] | @tsv'
```
Output:
```
'O'\\''Neill' 'd'\\''oh'
```
**Expected behavior**

`printf '%s ' 'O'\''Neill' 'd'\''oh'`
would output the expected
`O'Neill d'oh `

**Environment:**
 - Ubuntu 20.04, dash 0.5.10, jq 1.6

title: Build out of tree
body: Tests weren't happy with a setup like `mkdir -p build && cd build && ../configure && make`. `make check` now works on out-of-tree-builds. While I was making tests work, one of them failed for me due to Valgrind output, so that's fixed (I think with virtually no runtime costs; the biggest cost would be `strncpy()` instead of `strcpy()`, with lengths we already were computing). While I was making that test work, I noticed a function pointer cast error, so that's also received what should be a zero-cost patch (`always_inline`d function that exists solely to cast a parameter type and tail call the actual function). Another test failed due to my normal environment exporting `JQ_COLORS`, so that's now unset before all tests that try to use it. --- This change is‚ÄÇ[](https://reviewable.io/reviews/stedolan/jq/2183)
